claim: Water boils at different temperatures depending on altitude

supporting.text: The boiling point of water decreases with increasing altitude due to lower atmospheric pressure.

attacks.text: The boiling point of water decreases with increasing altitude due to lower atmospheric pressure.
The boiling point of water is only significantly affected at extreme altitudes, not in typical living conditions.
Even at moderate altitudes like 2000 meters, the boiling point drops noticeably (to around 93°C), affecting cooking and other processes.
Impurities in water can affect boiling point more than altitude in many practical scenarios.
While impurities do affect boiling point, the altitude effect is consistent and predictable, unlike variable impurity effects.

supporting.text: At sea level (1 atm pressure), water boils at 100°C, but at higher altitudes, it boils at lower temperatures.

attacks.text: At sea level (1 atm pressure), water boils at 100°C, but at higher altitudes, it boils at lower temperatures.
The boiling point of water is determined by its purity, not just altitude. Impurities can significantly alter the boiling point regardless of pressure.
While impurities can affect boiling point, the effect of altitude (pressure) is far more significant and predictable in most real-world scenarios.
Some high-altitude locations have microclimates or artificial pressure controls that negate the typical boiling point reduction.
Such cases are exceptional and do not invalidate the general rule that altitude lowers boiling point under natural conditions.

supporting.text: The relationship between altitude and boiling point is explained by the Clausius-Clapeyron equation in thermodynamics.

attacks.text: The relationship between altitude and boiling point is explained by the Clausius-Clapeyron equation in thermodynamics.
The Clausius-Clapeyron equation assumes ideal conditions and does not account for impurities or dissolved substances in water, which can also affect boiling point.
While impurities can affect boiling point, their impact is typically minor compared to the effect of altitude, especially for pure water under standard conditions.
The Clausius-Clapeyron equation is a theoretical model and may not perfectly predict boiling points in all real-world scenarios due to non-ideal behavior.
Empirical data consistently shows close agreement between the Clausius-Clapeyron predictions and observed boiling points at various altitudes, validating its practical use.

supporting.text: Empirical measurements confirm that water boils at approximately 95°C at 1,500 meters above sea level.

attacks.text: Empirical measurements confirm that water boils at approximately 95°C at 1,500 meters above sea level.
The boiling point of water is also influenced by impurities or dissolved substances, not just altitude.
While impurities affect boiling point, the effect of altitude is more significant and consistent in natural conditions.
The relationship between altitude and boiling point is not linear and varies based on atmospheric conditions.
Standard atmospheric models account for these variations, and the general trend of lower boiling points at higher altitudes remains valid.

supporting.text: Lower boiling points at high altitudes affect cooking times, as seen in mountainous regions.

attacks.text: Lower boiling points at high altitudes affect cooking times, as seen in mountainous regions.
The effect of altitude on boiling point is negligible for most practical cooking purposes below 2000 meters.
Even at moderate altitudes (1000-2000m), boiling point differences can significantly impact recipes requiring precise temperature control.
Modern pressure cookers eliminate altitude-related boiling point variations, making the original argument irrelevant for contemporary cooking.
Pressure cookers are not universally available in high-altitude regions where traditional cooking methods prevail.

supporting.text: Standard pressure cookers are used at high altitudes to increase the boiling point of water for efficient cooking.

attacks.text: Standard pressure cookers are used at high altitudes to increase the boiling point of water for efficient cooking.
Pressure cookers work by increasing the pressure inside the cooker, not by altering the boiling point of water at a given altitude.
While pressure cookers increase internal pressure, this effectively raises the boiling point of water relative to the external altitude conditions, supporting the original claim.
The boiling point of water is determined by atmospheric pressure, not altitude directly, which can vary even at the same altitude.
Altitude is a reliable proxy for atmospheric pressure in most practical scenarios, making the original claim broadly correct.
